content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and fun

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The problem description is unclear. "They have the option to take a break" implies that each contestant can choose to take a break or to complete the entire race without doing so. Therefore, the finishing order will depend on whether or not the contestants take their break. However, the rest of the problem assumes every contestant takes a break. See @sayankhanmidnapore and @jddingemanse's comments. @Bingbing and @JohnG.A's comments also apply. The wording has changed since the writing of their comments, but the core issue persists.

It is perfect, however you can add a variable which contain the speed after break because it is logic that a participant will restart with other speed after break. There, it is more difficult and close to reality

Optimally, none of the participants takes a break to finish with the best position possible. Rather than optional, making it incidental would make much more sense. I suggest changing the description of t to 'They take a break of t minutes during the race.' That way, there won't be any ambiguity about taking the break.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and easy.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

The description states that you need to calculate their time based on their average speed and that they can take a break. Average speed in general can contain uneven temporal speeds and even breaks. It would be cool if the break were included in the average speed; it is not atm.

As it is now, I would propose changing the average speed to "running average speed."
"They may or may not take a break" is confusing. I would just say "They must take a break"

i tried to reformulate the statement :
In an 8km running race, `n` participants with different letters compete. They have the option to take a break of `t` minutes during the race. Determine the order of finish for the runners based on their average speed, `s`.
What's a wonderful Clash! In my opinion, it would be better to give the race distance as a variable in Input instead of a constant number. That will make the challenge even more engaging)

It would add difficulty and still be reasonably short if user could skip providing the break time in case the participant didn't a break. Meaning that instead of getting zero in the input we just get nothing for example: A 34
The participant A is considered to have a speed of 34 and that he didn't take a break at all.
What's the point of 'They may or may not take a break...'? In the solution, the break is simply added to the time.

Input section
* Please mention that s and t are floats.

* Please mention that l, s and t are space-separated.

Cases
* The last pair of test and validator are the same. Please revise them so they are different.

Stub generator
* Please change the type of s and t to be "float".

* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer" or "write order").

Thanks.
